node.title: What Do You Say to the Sufferer?
node.description: An attempt to be present with a stranger in pain.
node.content: ["Several weeks ago, I gave a talk, and afterward the questions from the audience came to me on index cards. Most of the questions were about politics or society, but one card read: \u201cWhat do you do when you\u2019ve spent your life wanting to be dead?\u201d", "I didn\u2019t answer that card because I didn\u2019t know anything about the person who wrote it, and because I didn\u2019t know what to say. But it has haunted me and I\u2019ve kept the card on my night stand ever since.", "I wish I\u2019d said that I don\u2019t have any answers for you, but I do have a response. My response would start with the only things I know about you: You\u2019ve been through a lot of pain over the course of your life. You have amazing powers of endurance because you are still here. I know you\u2019re fighting still because you reached out to me. My response begins with deep respect for you.", "The other thing I know is that you are not alone. There is always a lot of suffering in the world, and over the past few years we have seen high tides of despair. The sources of people\u2019s pain may be different \u2014 grief, shame, exclusion, heartbreak, physical or mental health issues \u2014 but they almost always involve some feeling of isolation, of being cut off from others.", "In my own seasons of suffering, I\u2019ve been shocked at how emotional pain feels like searing physical pain in the stomach and chest, by how tempting it is to self-isolate and rob yourself of the very human contact you need most. But when it comes to extreme suffering, I must look to people who know more about it than I do, and one of those people is Viktor Frankl, who survived the Nazi death camps.", "Frankl argued that we often can\u2019t control what happens to us in life, that we can control only how we respond to it. If we respond to terrible circumstances with tenacity, courage, unselfishness and dignity, then we can add a deeper meaning to life. One can win small daily victories over hard circumstances.", "There were many people in the camps who wanted to die more than live. In \u201cMan\u2019s Search for Meaning,\u201d Frankl wrote that he would try to help them recognize that \u201clife was still expecting something from them; something in the future was expected of them.\u201d Frankl liked to paraphrase Nietzsche: \u201cHe who has a why to live for can bear with almost any how.\u201d", "The Bible is filled with characters who are at times overwhelmed with life and wish they could be rid of it \u2014 Jonah, Elijah, Job and even Moses. They are so central to the biblical story because desolation is part of the human experience, part of the bricks and mortar out of which we construct our lives.", "Suffering had such profound and unpredictable effects on those characters, as it does on all of us. Suffering can make people self-centered, loveless, humorless and angry. But we all know cases where suffering didn\u2019t break people but broke them open \u2014 made them more caring toward and knowledgeable about the suffering of others. And the old saying that we suffer our way to wisdom is not wrong. We often learn more from the hard times than the happy ones.", "And so we are right to treat those who have suffered with respect and credibility. \u201cWithout your wound where would your power be?\u201d Thornton Wilder wrote. \u201cIt is your very remorse that makes your low voice tremble into the hearts of men. The very angels themselves cannot persuade the wretched and blundering children on earth as can one human being broken on the wheels of living. In love\u2019s service only the wounded soldiers can serve.\u201d", "This doesn\u2019t mean that those who have suffered should go out giving sermons and lectures. We all know the weakness of words in these circumstances. But having tasted desolation, those who have suffered do powerfully sit with others in their desolation.", "Rabbi Elliot Kukla once described a woman with a brain injury who would sometimes fall to the floor. People around her would rush to immediately get her back on her feet, before she was quite ready. She told Kukla, \u201cI think people rush to help me up because they are so uncomfortable with seeing an adult lying on the floor. But what I really need is for someone to get down on the ground with me.\u201d", "Kukla pointed out that getting on the floor can be anxiety-producing and, when someone is in deep despair, even dangerous to the strongest caregiver. But sometimes you just get on the floor.", "We all need witnesses \u2014 to witness others, to be witnessed, to draw inspiration from each other. \u201cConsolation is an act of solidarity in space,\u201d Michael Ignatieff wrote in his new book, \u201cOn Consolation.\u201d", "I asked a pastor what he says to people in pain. One thing he says is, \u201cI want more for you.\u201d I repeat that sentence to you not with any illusion that the world does what I want, but simply as an expression of good will, an acknowledgment of how we all sit with our common fragility, and a recognition that life is unpredictable. It changes. In many pilgrims\u2019 progress, the slough of despond gives way to enchanted ground.", "If you are having thoughts of suicide, in the United States call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-8255 (TALK) or go to SpeakingOfSuicide.com/resources for a list of additional resources. Go here for resources outside the United States."]
